Cegah Komplikasi Diabetes untuk Menekan Biaya Pengobatan
06 Nov 2019, 12:31 by Antara, Yayuk Widiyarti
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Hati-hati buat mereka yang sudah menderita diabetes karena jika sudah terjadi komplikasi, penanganannya bisa semakin merepotkan dan menelan biaya besar. Prof. DR. dr. Ketut Suastika, Sp.PD (KEMD)., mengatakan bahwa pencegahan dapat menjadi cara untuk mengurangi beban biaya ekonomi yang besar.
"Saat dia mulai komplikasi biayanya meningkat, kalau diabetes belum komplikasi justru obatnya lebih murah. Misalnya, kalau komplikasi muncul penyakit jantung, ginjal, dan lainnya lalu masuk ICU dengan proses pemasangan alat dan sebagainya akan membutuhkan biaya yang besar hingga ratusan juta," katanya.
Ia mengatakan perlu adanya deteksi dini, terutama bagi yang memiliki faktor genetik dan perubahan pola makan yang sesuai sehingga komplikasi bisa dihindari. Menurutnya, diabetes menjadi salah satu penyakit dengan biaya ekonomi terbesar karena ketika sudah tercatat ada komplikasi pembiayaan untuk penanganannya tentu besar.
"Kalau misalnya diabetes dengan komplikasi ginjal kan harus cuci darah dan sebagainya, itu setiap minggu 2-8 kali, kalau rata-rata biayanya Rp 800 sampai Rp 1 juta, berarti setiap bulannya bisa menghabiskan Rp 8 juta untuk hemodialisis," katanya.
Seluruh pengobatan ini ditanggung BPJS, sehingga jika jumlah pasien bertambah bisa menimbulkan defisit bagi BPJS karena tanggungannya begitu besar, terutama pasien diabetes yang sudah mengalami komplikasi, seperti penyakit jantung, gagal ginjal (hemodialisa), sampai luka diabetes.
Menurutnya, jika masih konsumsi obat skala ringan, cukup di faskes 1, kalau dirujuk ke Rumah Sakit (faskes 2) biayanya justru akan bertambah, karena membayar dua kali.
"Jantung penyakit yang paling banyak menyerap anggaran BPJS karena jumlahnya banyak. Selainitu ada penyakit kanker, juga tinggi tapi jumlahnya tidak sebanyak jantung dan stroke. Kenaikan biaya ini juga mempengaruhi proses pembiayaan pasien dengan penyakit diabetes komplikasi," ucapnya.
"Kalau sudah stabil kondisinya dan mendapat obat yang sederhana, diusahakan berobat sampai di faskes 1, tidak harus ke faskes 2 karena itu bagi yang sudah masuk kategori komplikasi," lanjutnya.
Dalam penanganan pasien diabetes ini diperlukan fasilitas berupa pemeriksaan gula darah, pengadaan obat dilakukan secara berkelanjutan.

Prevent Diabetes Complications to Reduce Medical Costs
06 Nov 2019, 12:31 by Antara, Yayuk Widiyarti
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Be careful for those who already have diabetes because if complications occur, treatment can be even more troublesome and costly. Prof. DR. dr. Ketut Suastika, Sp.PD (KEMD)., Said that prevention can be a way to reduce the burden of large economic costs.
"When he started complications the cost would increase, if diabetes had not been complicated, the medicine would be cheaper. For example, if complications arose from heart, kidney and other diseases then entering the ICU with the process of installing tools and so on would require huge costs of up to hundreds of millions," he said.
He said the need for early detection, especially for those who have genetic factors and appropriate dietary changes so that complications can be avoided. According to him, diabetes has become one of the diseases with the biggest economic costs because when it has been noted there are financial complications for handling it is certainly large.
"For example diabetes with kidney complications must dialysis and so on, it is 2-8 times every week, if the average cost is Rp. 800 to Rp. 1 million, it means that each month can spend Rp. 8 million on hemodialysis," he said.
The whole treatment is borne by BPJS, so that if the number of patients increases it can cause a deficit for BPJS because the dependents are so large, especially diabetic patients who have experienced complications, such as heart disease, kidney failure (hemodialysis), to the wound of diabetes.
According to him, if you still consume mild scale medicine, it is enough in Health Facility 1, if you are referred to the Hospital (Health Facility 2) the cost will actually increase, because you pay twice.
"Heart disease absorbs the BPJS budget the most because there are a lot of it. Besides that there is cancer, it is also high, but the amount is not as much as heart disease and stroke. The increase in costs also affects the process of financing patients with complications of diabetes," he said.
"If the condition is stable and get a simple medicine, try to get treatment at health facilities 1, you don't have to go to health facilities 2 because it's for those who are already in the category of complications," he continued.
In handling this diabetic patient, facilities in the form of blood sugar checks are needed, and the supply of medicines is carried out on an ongoing basis.
